container-title: Mixed Agreements (Kluwer Law and Taxation Publishers
The European Union as an Actor in International Relations

In other mixed agreements, such as the Convention on the Law of the Sea or the Lomé Agreements between the EC and ACP countries, the EC and its Member States have—through a declaration—established their respective competences as regards the agreement in question. See Christian Tomuschat, supra note 19
title: '* Ibid. at paras 53 and 71. As noted by Christian Tomuschat, “Liability for Mixed Agreements’

if the EC and its Member States do not publish a declaration delimiting their competences concerning the Agreement in question, the other parties of the Agreement would not be obliged to verify such competences. See Ernest-Ulrich Petersmann, ‘International Activities of the European Union and Sovereignty of Member States’

container-title: In addition, Advocate General Jacobs in C-316/91, Parliament v
note: Council, ECR [1994] 1-625, at para. 69, observed that ‘[u]nder a mixed agreement the Com-munity and the Member States are jointly liable unless the provisions of the agreement point to
title: Joint responsibility from an international point of view in cases where the Member State violates the provisions in mixed agreements has been defended by many authors. See Eric Stein, External relations of the European Community: Structure and Process (Collected Courses of the Academy of European Law
Christiane Tomuschat, supra note 19
The European Community’s Rights and Obligations under Mixed Agreements’
